nodes.text: THE PROCESS OF THERAPEUTIC CHANGE  INVOLVING IMPLICIT KNOWLEDGE:  SOME IMPLICATIONS OF DEVELOPMENTAL  OBSERVATIONS FOR ADULT PSYCHOTHERAPY

nodes.text: is the “moment of meeting,” in which the participants interact in a way that creates a new implicit,  intersubjective understanding of their relationship and permits a new “way-of-being-with-the-other.” We  view “moments of meeting” as the key element in bringing about change in implicit knowledge, just as  interpretations are thought to be the key element in bringing about change in explicit knowledge.

nodes.text: Four things impressed us most in listening to and studying in detail the process notes of  psychodynamically oriented therapies:

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: Much of the mutative action involves that broad domain of intelligence called implicit  (procedural) knowledge,

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The microprocess of proceeding in a therapy session seems to occur in an improvisa-  tional mode

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: During a session, points of mutative potential arise at unpremeditated “moments.”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: “now moments.” Such  moments are viewed as emergent properties of a complex, dynamic system

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: When “now moments” are handled by the patient and therapist so as to achieve a  “specific moment of meeting,” the implicit knowledge of each partner gets altered by  creating a new and different intersubjective context between them—the relationship  has changed. This process requires no interpretation and need not be made verbally  explicit.

nodes.text: CONCEPTS AND TERMS FOR DESCRIBING THE  THERAPEUTIC PROCESS

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: 1. “Moving Along”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: In this initial stage (no. 1), they start to work together. Most often there is a goal in sight that  can last for variable periods of time

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: Each step in this moving along process is called a “present moment.”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: This kind of improvisational, self-finding, and self-correcting process is what we have  come to be familiar from Tronick’s characterization of the parent–infant interactive process  consisting of matches-mismatches, ruptures and repairs (Tronick & Weinberg, 1997; see Tron-  ick, this issue).

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The realization that so much occurs in the improvisational mode between parent and infant  has made clear the importance of the repair of ruptures and the midcourse corrections that such  a process needs (Tronick, 1989; see Lyons-Ruth this issue)

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: In fact, coming to implicitly know  how to repair and redirect the improvisational process is one of the main hidden agendas of  the parent–infant interaction

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: Moreover, in the parent–infant inter-  action, the repetition of many activities has a quality of moving along that creates a repertoire  of present moments.

nodes.text: 2. “Now Moments”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: In the course of the moving along process, all of a sudden a qualitatively different and unpre-  dicted moment arises

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: This is a “hot” present moment, a sort of “moment of truth” which is  affectively charged.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: It is also laden with potential importance for the immediate or long-term  future.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: It is also a moment that pulls the two participants fully into the present

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The “now moment” is seen as an emergent property of the complex dynamic system made  up of two people moving along in the therapeutic process

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: This emergent moment challenges  or threatens the stability of the ongoing initial state

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: It announces a disturbance in the system  (state no. 1) that constitutes a potential transition to a new state of organization

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The “now moment,” as an emergent property, disequilibrates the normal,  canonical way of doing business together.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: It offers a new intersubjective context.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: For this  reason, it is difficult and challenging clinically. It requires a deviation from the usual technical  moves used by that dyad

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: When a “now moment” emerges, the therapist and the patient are surprised, in the sense  of taken off guard

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: a nonlinear jump

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: In the adult patient–therapist dyad, the emergent properties arise  from the inherent workings of that complex dynamic system. In infancy preprogrammed de-  velopmental shifts, as well as the intrinsic mutual regulatory working of the system, create  emergent properties within the dyadic system (Tronick, 1989, and this issue).

nodes.text: 3. A “Moment of Meeting”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: A “now moment” that is therapeutically seized and mutually recognized can become a “moment  of meeting.”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: This requires that each partner contributes something unique and authentic as an  individual in response to a “now moment.”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The response cannot be an application of technique  nor an habitual therapeutic move. It must be created on the spot to fit the singularity of the  unexpected situation, and it must carry the therapist’s signature as coming from his own sen-  sibility and experience, beyond technique and theory

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: when this enactment has been performed, mutually recognized and ratified, will a  new intersubjective state come into being

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The end result is a change in both members implicit relational knowing.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: 4. An “Open Space”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: Immediately after a “moment of meeting,” Sander (1988) observed that an “open space” occurs  in the infant–parent interactive process in which the partners disengage from their specific  meeting and can be alone, in the presence of the other.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: similar pause is observed in adult  psychotherapy. It is assumed that during this open space each participant can assimilate

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: effect of the moment of meeting in finding a new equilibrium in the altered intersubjective  state that they now inhabit.

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: After the open space has finished, the two partners take up again the “moving along”  process,

nodes.text: SUMMARY

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: The major findings are the  realization that even in a “talking therapy,” a vast amount of therapeutic change occurs in the  realm of procedural knowledge that is not conscious, especially implicit knowledge of how to  act, feel, and think when in a particular relational context (implicit relational knowing). We  suggest that the mutative act in this domain is a specific “moment of meeting,”

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: which is an  emergent property of the dyadic system that pushes it into a new state of intersubjectivity—

ref.doc: stern98 -- therapeutic change __ strern, daniel n

nodes.text: —thus, changing the relationship.
